description: From a- (“on”) + Middle English baft, baften, biaften, Old English beæftan; be (“by”) (modern English by) + æftan (“behind”) (modern English after). See also aft.

adverbs.description: abaft (comparative more abaft, superlative most abaft)

entries.meaning: (nautical) On the aft side; in the stern. [First attested in the early 17th century.]
examples: We drifted with the wind abaft.

entries.meaning: (nautical, obsolete) Backwards. [Attested from around (1150 to 1350) until the late 15th century.]
(nautical) Behind; toward the stern relative to some other object or position; aft of. [First attested around the late 15th century.]
examples: The captain stood abaft the wheelhouse.
